title: Eukaryotic Animal Cells - Mitochondria & Cytoskeleton
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Structure and function of mitochondria (energy production, endosymbiotic theory) and the cytoskeleton (microfilaments, intermediate filaments, microtubules).
learningIntentions: Students can describe the structure of mitochondria and explain aerobic respiration stages.
Students can outline the evidence supporting the endosymbiotic theory.
Students can distinguish between the three cytoskeletal components by size and function.
Students can explain how the cytoskeleton enables cell movement and division.

engagementHook.title: Powerhouse of the Cell
engagementHook.content: Your body produces about 70 kg of ATP every day—more than your body weight! Mitochondria are responsible for this energy production. But mitochondria weren't always part of our cells. Two billion years ago, they were free-living bacteria that entered a partnership. What evidence suggests mitochondria have a bacterial origin? And how does their structure reflect this ancient ancestry?

keyConcepts.definition: Double-membraned organelle producing ATP via aerobic respiration. Contains own DNA (circular) and 70S ribosomes. Site of Krebs cycle (matrix) and electron transport chain (inner membrane).
Folded inner mitochondrial membrane. Increases surface area for electron transport chain and ATP synthase. More cristae = more energy production.
Mitochondria (and chloroplasts) evolved from free-living prokaryotes engulfed by ancestral eukaryotic cells. Evidence: double membrane, own DNA, 70S ribosomes, similar size to bacteria.
Thinnest cytoskeletal element (7nm). Made of actin. Involved in muscle contraction, cell division (cleavage furrow), cell crawling, shape changes.
Medium-sized (10nm). Various proteins (keratin, vimentin, lamins). Provides mechanical strength, anchors organelles, maintains cell shape.
Thickest (25nm). Hollow tubes of tubulin (α and β). Forms spindle fibres, cilia, flagella, tracks for organelle transport.

misconceptions.misconception: Mitochondria have 80S ribosomes like the cytoplasm
misconceptions.correction: Mitochondria have 70S ribosomes (like bacteria), not 80S. This is key evidence for endosymbiotic theory.

misconceptions.misconception: All cells have the same number of mitochondria
misconceptions.correction: Mitochondrial number varies by energy demand. Heart muscle cells have 5,000+; skin cells have fewer. Cells can make more mitochondria (mitochondrial biogenesis).

misconceptions.misconception: The cytoskeleton is just a skeleton
misconceptions.correction: Unlike a skeleton, the cytoskeleton is dynamic—constantly assembling and disassembling. It enables movement, not just structure.

contentSections.title: Mitochondrial Structure
contentSections.content: Mitochondria have an outer membrane (permeable to small molecules) and a highly folded inner membrane (impermeable, contains electron transport proteins). The space between is the intermembrane space; the internal compartment is the matrix. The matrix contains mitochondrial DNA (circular), 70S ribosomes, and enzymes for the Krebs cycle.
keyPoints: Double membrane: outer smooth, inner folded into cristae
Cristae increase surface area for ATP production
Matrix contains own DNA and 70S ribosomes
Mitochondria divide by binary fission (like bacteria)
contentSections.example: Brown fat mitochondria have many cristae (thermogenesis). Flight muscle in birds has mitochondria packed with cristae for sustained energy.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why does the inner mitochondrial membrane need to be impermeable while the outer membrane is permeable?

contentSections.title: Evidence for Endosymbiotic Theory

items: Can divide independently by binary fission

contentSections.note: The same evidence applies to chloroplasts in plants (cyanobacterial origin).
contentSections.example: Mitochondrial DNA is inherited only from mother. This allows tracing maternal lineages (mitochondrial Eve). Antibiotics that target bacterial 70S ribosomes can affect mitochondrial function.

contentSections.title: The Cytoskeleton: Three Components
contentSections.content: The cytoskeleton is a network of protein filaments extending throughout the cytoplasm. It provides structural support, enables cell movement, and facilitates intracellular transport. Microfilaments (7nm) are the thinnest and enable muscle contraction. Intermediate filaments (10nm) provide mechanical strength. Microtubules (25nm) are hollow tubes that form tracks for organelle movement and make up cilia, flagella, and the mitotic spindle.
keyPoints: Microfilaments: actin; muscle contraction, cell division
Microtubules: tubulin; spindle, cilia, intracellular transport
All are dynamic—constantly polymerising and depolymerising
contentSections.example: During mitosis, microtubules form the spindle that pulls chromosomes apart. In muscle, actin and myosin filaments slide past each other to contract. Keratin in skin cells provides toughness.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why do dividing cells need to reorganise their microtubules?

activities.title: Surface Area to Volume Ratio
activities.description: Calculate how mitochondrial cristae increase surface area for energy production.
activities.learningObjective: Apply mathematical understanding to cellular structures.

questions.question: A mitochondrion has a spherical inner membrane with radius 0.5 µm. The surface area of a sphere is 4πr². If cristae increase the inner membrane surface area 15-fold, what is the total surface area available for the electron transport chain? (Use π = 3.14)
questions.hint: First calculate sphere SA: 4 × 3.14 × (0.5)² = 3.14 µm². Then multiply by 15 for cristae folding.

multipleChoice.question: Which of the following is evidence that mitochondria evolved from free-living bacteria?
options: They are surrounded by a single membrane
They contain 80S ribosomes like the cytoplasm
They have circular DNA and 70S ribosomes
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: They have circular DNA and 70S ribosomes
multipleChoice.rationale: Circular DNA and 70S ribosomes are prokaryotic features. Mitochondria have double membranes (from engulfment), not single. They can divide independently by binary fission.

multipleChoice.question: The electron transport chain is located in the:
multipleChoice.rationale: The inner mitochondrial membrane contains the protein complexes of the electron transport chain. The matrix contains Krebs cycle enzymes. The outer membrane is permeable and lacks these proteins.

multipleChoice.question: Which cytoskeletal element is responsible for separating chromosomes during cell division?
multipleChoice.rationale: Microtubules form the mitotic spindle that attaches to chromosomes and pulls them apart. Actin forms the cleavage furrow (cytokinesis), not chromosome separation.

shortAnswer.question: Explain how the structure of cristae relates to their function in ATP production. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Cristae are folds of the inner mitochondrial membrane
1 mark: Folding increases surface area for electron transport chain and ATP synthase
1 mark: More surface area = more protein complexes = greater ATP production capacity
shortAnswer.commonError: Confusing cristae with the matrix; not explaining the surface area advantage

definitions: Mitochondrion: Double-membraned organelle producing ATP; contains own circular DNA and 70S ribosomes.
Cristae: Folds of inner mitochondrial membrane; increase surface area for ATP production.
Endosymbiotic theory: Mitochondria evolved from engulfed bacteria; evidence: 70S ribosomes, circular DNA, double membrane.
Microfilament: 7nm actin filament; muscle contraction, cell division, cell crawling.
Microtubule: 25nm hollow tube; spindle, cilia, flagella, organelle transport.
keyPoints: Mitochondria have own DNA (circular) and 70S ribosomes—evidence for bacterial origin
Cristae increase surface area for electron transport chain
Microtubules form spindle, cilia, and transport tracks
diagrams: Labelled mitochondrion showing cristae and membranes

shortAnswer: Cristae are folds of the inner mitochondrial membrane that dramatically increase the surface area available for the electron transport chain and ATP synthase enzymes. This increased surface area allows more protein complexes to be embedded in the membrane, thereby increasing the mitochondrion's capacity for ATP production. Cells with high energy demands, such as muscle cells, have mitochondria with particularly abundant cristae.
